title.rendered: US Treasury: NFTs Could Present Illicit Financial Risks

content.rendered:
Money laundering, scam or whatever you want to call it, be warned if you plan to buy an NFT in the hope of some kind of return or value

Earlier this week, the US Department of the Treasury issued a warning that non-fungible tokens (NFTs) could be used for money laundering. It’s something that many who have been watching activities in the NFT space for a while have independently concluded.

After the official report is published, we can say that slowly but surely, governments around the world are starting to wake up to the schemes, scams and criminal activity in the NFT industry. The study was commissioned by Congress in the Anti-Money Laundering Act of 2020.

Twitter user Nikhil D Prince ironized through his user @NikhilDPrince:

I have 2 million dollars in Ether.

I create an NFT piece.

I use my $2M to buy my own NFT.

I still have my $2M worth of ETH, and I also have an NFT piece worth $2M based on price history.

Selling my #NFT to someone for just $200K, or 90% off!

I now have $2.2M in ETH.

CtrlC+V

I have $2M in Ether.
I create an NFT piece.
I use my $2M to buy my own NFT.
I still have my $2M in ETH, and I also have an NFT piece that is worth $2M according to price history.
I sell my #NFT to someone for only $200K, or at a 90% discount!
Now I have $2.2M in ETH.
CtrlC+V

— Nikhil D Prince 🇮🇳 (@NikhilDPrince) April 10, 2021

This could be whitewashing, or it could just be a scam. Either way, many say that is what is happening in a market that, according to industry estimates, could reach $35 billion in 2022 and more than $80 billion in 2025.

For more context, according to Dappradar, NFT sales volume totaled $24.9 billion in 2021, up from $94.9 million a year earlier.

“Be warned when buying NFT”

The treasure recognized that NFTs offer new opportunities in the creative arts and media. However, also warned that NFTs could allow criminals to use illicit funds to make seemingly legitimate art purchases.

The Agency explained that the portable nature of NFTs, which can be moved internationally and instantly, makes them susceptible to use in money laundering schemes. He pointed to the lack of financial, regulatory, or investigative costs of physical shipping as reasons why NFTs may be attractive to criminals seeking to launder funds.

The blockchain data platform chain analysiswhose objective is to shed light on what happens in the different chains, countered this claim saying that NFTs account for a small portion of all crimes committed in the digital assets sector. Considering the scale of crime that occurs across the board, that does not necessarily mean that the level of crime involved in NFTs is insignificant.

What criminals don’t know

Although the Treasury is concerned about the possibility of NFTs being used for money laundering, it seems to understand something that would-be criminals do not. who use them for those purposes. In its report, the Treasury states:

“The exchange of an NFT transfers that ownership between digital wallets or smart contracts, and because they are blockchain-based, NFTs are publicly verifiable, auditable, and digitally unique due to being cryptographically derived.”

In other words, there is a digital trail for every transaction, and once a record of it is recorded on a public blockchain, the evidence of that transaction is there forever.

Face the consequences

Eventually, when the US non-hosted wallet rule and new European Union rules banning anonymous transactions come into force; Either criminals will hold valuable NFTs in wallets they cannot sell, or their schemes will immediately become publicly visible to investigators, who will connect the dots as they figure out who owns each wallet.

Furthermore, when platforms like Opensea become responsible for handling the proceeds of crime, they will implement their own controls that will make it doubly difficult to buy and sell crime-linked NFTs.

Buyers and traders of NFTs should also be aware of the potential consequences of handling NFTs that may have been traded by criminals. Although the most sensible voices have been warning for years of the consequences of manipulating digital objects linked to crime, some are still surprised when it happens to them.
